instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message:
Hi All.

Just wanted to see if I can get some assistance with a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> I'm working on. Board while looking clean had it's liquid marker tripped by <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>. Board started off as fluctuating between 0.0157A @ 5.1762V to 0.0132A - 5.1751V 0.190A. Went through and checked the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> bootup table on logiwiki. Found all LDOs (step 2) are present bar <SIGNAL>P1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> which is completely missing regardless which USB port I use and <SIGNAL>P1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> which is 0.280V, Logiwiki noted that's likely a faulty TBT rom, and judging the sticker near it had tripped I decided to remove the rom and low and behold there was junk under it. Replaced it and now the boards up to 0.0230 with a short dip to 0.01 and a short spike to 0.04 than rinse and repeat. 
After replacing the TBT rom it shortly did get warm, not hot but it was evaporating IPA after maybe 40 sec or so, but after leaving it on for a minute or so and power cycling it's no longer doing that. Nothing else seems to be getting hot. Confirmed all traces between the TBT rom and the CDs are ok, as logi also mentions they often break.    

What else could be causing PP1v1 to be missing? Besides bad CDs hopefully because I do not have replacements. 

Thanks for your assistance.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message:
1V1 LDO must appear only on the powered port.

Did you replace <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> from donor board, same model?
Check all surrounding resistors.

Do you get L6995 voltage?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message:
Ah didn’t know that, thanks. I assumed that since these have a master and a slave CD, since the slave has to communicate through the master to the rom chip, that the masters ldo would be present when using its port but not the slaves, but when using the slaves port both would be present.


No I used a tbt rom from the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I was trying to fix as it was the only other board I had with that same chip and hoped the firmware would be the same.

<RESISTOR>R2893</RESISTOR> is 3209 ohms in circuit <RESISTOR>R2892</RESISTOR> is 3249 ohms in circuit, and <RESISTOR>R2891</RESISTOR> is 3.27K ohms in circuit. Not sure why my meter decided to measure the top two in ohms measurements and the last in k measurements caught me out for a second there I thought the first 2 it was saying 320.9k ohms. surrounding resistors around the TBT rom all measure ok, and also checked <RESISTOR>R3000</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3001</RESISTOR> since the wiki points those out as well.

Yes I’m getting 3.42V which is a bit high, isn’t it suppose to be 3.3v?  One other thing I noticed, I went on and did steps 3-12 on the CD table and <SIGNAL>HV_GATE</SIGNAL> 1 is 10.89v and gate 2 is 7.14v when the table says it should be 5v until the charger switches to 20v than it boosts to 20v for the pros.  Not sure if that’s relevant  though just thought I should mention.

Should also mention both CD fuses have been checked and both have 5.12v when their respective USB port is connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message:
Just checked the voltages on the no stuff caps as well as I noticed in another post last year you requested those.


<CAPACITOR>C3120</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.12v / pad 2: 4.19V
<CAPACITOR>C3121</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 4.56v dips to 4.31 than back up
pad 2: 8.36 fluctuates all over the place quite rapidly. Lowest value was 6.35v.

<CAPACITOR>C3220</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.16v / pad 2: 7.2v
<CAPACITOR>C3221</CAPACITOR> pad 1: 5.15V dips to 4.82v than back up
 pad 2: 10.86V dips to 9.75v after about 20 sec but bounced back to 10.86 immediately.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message:
STOP wasting time!
Put first correct <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>; it has firmware, specific for each board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message: After the board numbers they usually have a dash something do we know what that denotes? I'm assuming probably a region designation. I did get a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A donor board today, but the board I need a rom for is <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-1. Does that matter? I've ordered some TBT roms from our local electronics supplier incase it does need to be the exact same one and will flash one once they arrive since I've been told these are actually flashable unlike most Apple chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message:
The last digit should'n be important here.

Did you try to read the original <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>(lowXB)_LDO_BMC - All other LDOs present
threads.message: Not yet, I do not have a programmer ATM so I was not able to. In the order of purchasing the roms, I also purchased a programmer. Also saw chipsetpro offer A <CHIP>U2980</CHIP> programmer, are they any good? Might get one of those as well.
